title: Quiz 6: Comprehensive Review Paper 1 (Part A)
description: Comprehensive revision quiz covering Medical-Surgical, Midwifery, and General Nursing (Questions 1-25).

questions.question: A patient with common bile duct obstruction related to cancer of the pancreas is likely to present with:
questions.explanation: Obstructive jaundice prevents bilirubin from entering the gut (causing pale stools) but causes conjugated bilirubin to back up into the blood (scleral icterus) and be excreted by kidneys (dark urine).
questions.hint: Think about where the bile goes if it can't get into the intestine.

questions.question: Monochorionic twinning is always characterized by:
questions.explanation: Monochorionic twins share a single placenta and outer membrane (chorion). They may have separate inner sacs (amnions), but the defining feature is the shared chorion/placenta.
questions.hint: Mono- means one; Chorion refers to the placenta/outer membrane.

questions.question: Following hemorrhoidectomy the nurse should:

options.text: Ensure the patient sits on a soft cushion for the first three days
Advise the patient to only request for a bland diet
Ensure the patient has a sitz bath after every bowel action
Remove the anal pack 8 hours after surgery

questions.explanation: Sitz baths cleanse the area, improve circulation, and reduce pain/spasm, especially after bowel movements.
questions.hint: Hygiene and comfort are priorities after a bowel movement in this case.

questions.question: The left kidney is slightly lower than the right kidney.
questions.explanation: The RIGHT kidney is lower because of the large liver occupying space on the right side of the abdomen.
questions.hint: Which organ pushes the kidney down on the right side?

questions.question: Which event of fetal development happens during 8-12 weeks gestation?

options.text: Fetal heart heard on auscultation, vernix caseosa appears
Fetus responds to sound, eyelids close
Finger nails can be seen, gender determined

questions.explanation: By 12 weeks, differentiation of external genitalia is complete (gender determined) and nail beds are forming. Vernix and Lanugo appear later (2nd trimester).
questions.hint: This is the end of the first trimester.

questions.question: The diagonal conjugate is measured anteroposteriorly from:

options.text: Lower border of symphysis to sacropromontory
Upper border of symphysis to sacropromontory
From anterior of symphysis to the sacropromontory

questions.explanation: The diagonal conjugate is measured during a vaginal exam by reaching from the lower edge of the pubic symphysis to the sacral promontory.
questions.hint: It is measured from the bottom of the pubic bone.

questions.question: A late manifestation of compartment syndrome is:
questions.explanation: Pain is the earliest sign. Pulselessness is a very late sign indicating total arterial occlusion and likely irreversible damage.
questions.hint: If you wait for this sign, it might be too late to save the limb.

questions.question: Which of the following are characteristics of the chorion membrane?

options.text: Tears to the edge of placenta, tough, smooth
Tears to cord insertion, tough, smooth
Tears to cord insertion, opaque, thick
Opaque, thick, tears to the edge of placenta

questions.explanation: The chorion is the rough, thick, opaque outer membrane attached to the placenta's edge. The amnion is smooth and tough.
questions.hint: Chorion = Outer = Opaque.

questions.question: The personality disorder associated with being insensitive to others and abusive behavior without remorse is:
questions.explanation: Antisocial Personality Disorder involves a pattern of disregarding rights of others, lack of empathy/remorse, and often criminal behavior.
questions.hint: This individual acts against society's norms.

questions.question: The clinical features for kidney rejection post transplantation includes:
questions.explanation: Rejection causes the kidney to fail (oliguria, fluid retention/weight gain) and inflammation (tenderness), leading to hypertension.
questions.hint: Signs of kidney failure and fluid overload.

questions.question: On abdominal examination during labour, the sinciput is felt and occiput is 'just felt'. The descent is:
questions.explanation: If the occiput is only 'just felt' above the brim while the sinciput is felt, it indicates the head is engaging, typically corresponding to 3/5 palpable.
questions.hint: The head is going down, but not fully engaged yet.

questions.question: A classification of ringworms that infect the finger nails is:
questions.explanation: Tinea unguium (Onychomycosis) affects the nails.
questions.hint: 'Unguium' refers to the nail.

questions.question: When estimating the size of burns, the palm of the patient's hand represents a total body surface area of:
questions.explanation: The 'Rule of Palms' states the patient's palm (including fingers) is roughly 1% TBSA.
questions.hint: It's a small unit of measure for patchy burns.

questions.question: The prophylactic drugs given to a term newborn at birth are:

options.text: 3% tetracycline eye ointment, vit. K 0.5mg i.m.
Gentamycin eye drops, vit K. i.m.
1% tetracycline eye ointment, vit K, 1 mg i.m. stat
Gentamycin eye drop, vit. K 1 mg 1.m.

questions.explanation: Standard prophylaxis is Tetracycline 1% for eyes (ophthalmia neonatorum) and Vitamin K 1mg IM (hemorrhagic disease) for term babies.
questions.hint: Term babies get the full 1mg dose of Vit K.

questions.question: The process of immersing used dressing instruments in dilute hibitane solution is known as:
questions.explanation: Immersion immediately after use to kill some pathogens and make items safer to handle is decontamination.
questions.hint: The first step in infection control cycle for instruments.

questions.question: Specific defence mechanisms are achieved by:
questions.explanation: Phagocytosis and inflammation are non-specific. Cell-mediated immunity (involving T-cells) targets specific antigens.
questions.hint: This involves memory and specific targeting.

questions.question: The cycle where bile salts excreted by the liver are absorbed by the intestine and returned to the liver is:
questions.explanation: Entero (intestine) + Hepatic (liver) circulation recycles bile salts.
questions.hint: The name combines 'intestine' and 'liver'.

questions.question: When a midwife closes the curtains, he/she minimizes heat loss by:
questions.explanation: Closing curtains blocks drafts (air currents), preventing convective heat loss. It also blocks the cold window surface, reducing radiation heat loss, but preventing drafts is usually the primary convective intervention.
questions.hint: Stopping air currents.

questions.question: Which of the following are Gram negative bacilli? (Select the best group)
questions.explanation: E. coli, Salmonella, and Shigella are all gram-negative rods (bacilli). Staph/Strep are gram-positive cocci.
questions.hint: Common causes of gut infections.

questions.question: Management of impetigo involves:
questions.explanation: Impetigo is bacterial, treated with antibiotics. Corticosteroids suppress immunity and are contraindicated.
questions.hint: It is a bacterial skin infection.

questions.question: Lochia Rubra is characterized by:

options.text: Occurs 1st - 4th day, contains blood, shreds of decidua

questions.explanation: Rubra (Red) is the first stage of lochia, consisting mainly of blood and decidual tissue.
questions.hint: Rubra means Red.

questions.question: Transurethral incision of the prostate (TUIP) or TURP is indicated for:

options.text: Initial stages of benign prostatic hypertrophy
Benign prostatic hypertrophy causing complete urinary obstruction

questions.explanation: Surgery is indicated when BPH causes complications like obstruction, retention, or renal damage.
questions.hint: When medical management fails or blockage is complete.

questions.question: Reed-Sternberg cell is a pathologic hallmark essential in diagnosis of:
questions.explanation: These giant cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin's Lymphoma.
questions.hint: The Owl's Eye cell.

questions.question: Which hormonal family planning methods can be given to a mother at six weeks post partum?

options.text: Implants, progesterone only injectable, progesterone only pills
Progesterone only pills, combined oral contraceptives
Progesterone only pills, condoms, intra-uterine device
Progesterone only injectable, combined oral pills

questions.explanation: Breastfeeding mothers should avoid estrogen (Combined pills) as it reduces milk supply. Progestin-only methods are safe.
questions.hint: Avoid Estrogen while breastfeeding.

questions.question: From 28-32 weeks of gestation, which developmental changes occur to the fetus?

options.text: Skin becomes pale and less wrinkled, plantar creases visible
Stores fat and iron, testes descend into scrotum, lanugo disappears from face
Ear cartilage becomes firm, stores fat and iron
Lanugo disappears from the face, vernix caseosa disappears

questions.explanation: Between 28-32 weeks, subcutaneous fat deposits increase (smoothing skin), iron stores build up, and testes begin their descent into the scrotum (completed closer to term).
questions.hint: Focus on preparation for birth: fat storage and iron reserves.

questions.question: When plotting findings on a partograph, obstructed labour would be indicated by:

options.text: Poor cervical dilatation, foetal distress, clear liquor
Slow descent, mild uterine contractions, early rupture of membranes
Fetal distress, clear liquor, mild uterine contractions
Slow descent, poor cervical dilatation, early rupture of membranes

questions.explanation: Obstructed labor is characterized by arrest of dilatation (crossing Action Line) and arrest of descent despite strong contractions. Early membrane rupture is common.
questions.hint: Progress stops (dilatation/descent) despite effort.

questions.question: During pregnancy, physiological haemodilution reaches its peak at:
questions.explanation: Plasma volume expansion peaks around 32-34 weeks, outstripping red blood cell mass increase, resulting in the lowest hemoglobin concentration (physiologic anemia).
questions.hint: It happens early in the third trimester.

questions.question: The primary reason for administering digoxin (Lanoxin) to a patient is to:

options.text: Relax the walls of the heart’s arteries
Improve the strength of the heart beat
Decrease inflammation of the heart wall

questions.explanation: Digoxin is a positive inotrope, meaning it increases the force of myocardial contraction, improving cardiac output in heart failure.
questions.hint: It makes the pump stronger.

questions.question: What is the therapeutic effect of cardiac glycosides like Digoxin?
questions.explanation: Digoxin increases intracellular calcium in heart muscle cells, leading to a stronger contraction (Positive Inotropy) while slowing the heart rate (Negative Chronotropy).
questions.hint: It helps the heart pump harder, not faster.

questions.question: A baby born of a mother on Anti-TB drugs (initial phase) should:

options.text: Get Isoniazid 5 mg/Kg twice daily for 3 months
Get Isoniazid 5 mg/Kg once daily for 6 months

questions.explanation: Infants exposed to active TB (via mother) require Isoniazid Preventive Therapy (IPT) for 6 months to prevent infection. BCG is often deferred until IPT is complete.
questions.hint: Prophylaxis lasts half a year.

questions.question: Caput succedaneum is defined as:

options.text: Collection of blood under the periosteum
A swelling under the scalp (subcutaneous edema)

questions.explanation: Caput is edema of the scalp soft tissue that crosses suture lines. Cephalohematoma (Option A) is blood under the periosteum that does NOT cross suture lines.
questions.hint: Fluid under the skin that crosses suture lines.

questions.question: The priority nursing diagnosis for a patient with heart failure and pulmonary oedema is:

options.text: Risk for infection related to stasis
Impaired skin integrity related to pressure
Activity intolerance related to pump failure / Impaired Gas Exchange

questions.explanation: Pulmonary edema impairs gas exchange and cardiac output, leading to severe activity intolerance and hypoxia. This is the physiological priority (ABC).
questions.hint: Breathing and circulation take precedence over skin and bowels.

questions.question: The 'Sensitivity' part of a Culture & Sensitivity test determines:

options.text: The most effective antibiotics against the organism
The antibiotics the patient is allergic to
The concentration of bacteria in the blood

questions.explanation: Culture grows and identifies the organism. Sensitivity tests which antibiotics effectively kill it.
questions.hint: It tells the doctor which drug will work.

questions.question: Acute angle closure glaucoma is a medical emergency.
questions.explanation: Acute angle closure glaucoma causes a rapid rise in intraocular pressure which can lead to permanent blindness within hours if not treated.
questions.hint: Pressure builds up rapidly and can destroy the optic nerve.

questions.question: The primary rationale for tube feeding a client post total laryngectomy is to:

options.text: Meet dietary needs and prevent fistula formation
Prevent aspiration (Note: Laryngectomy separates airway from esophagus)

questions.explanation: After laryngectomy, the pharynx is sutured. Oral feeding stresses this suture line and can cause a pharyngocutaneous fistula. Tube feeding bypasses this area during healing.
questions.hint: Protecting the surgical suture line in the throat.

questions.question: When a blood pressure reading is abnormal upon initial assessment, the best action is to:

options.text: Check the BP on the other arm
Take it on both arms sitting and standing immediately
Check with the patient standing only

questions.explanation: Checking the contralateral arm verifies the finding and rules out vascular anomalies (like subclavian stenosis).
questions.hint: Verify accuracy by using the opposite limb.

questions.question: Which technique should be AVOIDED when moving a hemiplegic client in bed?

options.text: Sliding the client to move them up
Rolling the client onto the side
Lifting the client with a draw sheet
Using a trapeze if upper body strength allows

questions.explanation: Sliding creates shearing forces and friction, which tears skin and damages tissues, especially in immobile patients. Lifting (using a draw sheet) is the correct technique.
questions.hint: Friction damages the skin.

questions.question: Neurovascular assessment of a limb (The 5 Ps) involves checking: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Neurovascular checks assess circulation (Color, Temp, Pulse) and nerve function (Sensation, Movement).
questions.hint: Remember 'CMS': Circulation, Motion, Sensation.

questions.question: The risk for macrovascular complications in diabetes mellitus is best reduced by:

options.text: Weight reduction, lipid management, quitting smoking

questions.explanation: Macrovascular disease (Stroke, Heart Attack) is driven by atherosclerosis. Addressing cardiovascular risk factors (Lipids, Smoking, Obesity, BP) is the primary prevention strategy.
questions.hint: Focus on heart health and lifestyle factors.

questions.question: A diet consisting EXCLUSIVELY of which foods may predispose a client to megaloblastic anemia?
questions.explanation: Megaloblastic anemia is caused by B12 or Folate deficiency. Grains like Sorghum/Millet alone lack B12 (found in animal products) and may be low in Folate if not fortified or eaten with legumes/greens.
questions.hint: A diet lacking both animal products and green leafy vegetables/legumes.

questions.question: Nursing interventions for a patient with multiple myeloma include:
questions.explanation: High fluid intake is critical to prevent renal failure caused by hypercalcemia and the accumulation of Bence-Jones proteins in the kidney tubules.
questions.hint: Flush the kidneys to prevent stones and failure.

questions.question: In positioning a casted leg immediately after application, the nurse should:

options.text: Keep leg flat for 3 hours then elevate
Elevate the leg on a pillow continuously for 24-48 hours

questions.explanation: Elevation above heart level reduces swelling (edema) during the initial inflammatory phase, preventing compartment syndrome and improving comfort.
questions.hint: Gravity helps drain fluid away from the injury.

questions.question: Drugs used in the management of Meniere’s disease include:
questions.explanation: Treatment involves Diuretics (reduce fluid), Antihistamines (suppress vestibular system), and Antiemetics (control nausea).
questions.hint: Reduce fluid pressure and control dizziness/nausea.

questions.question: Normal Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Normal CSF is clear and colorless ('gin clear'). It contains glucose (about 2/3 of blood glucose) and protein, but no RBCs and very few WBCs.
questions.hint: It should look like water.

questions.question: Insertion of a urinary catheter in a female patient is facilitated by requesting the patient to:
questions.explanation: Asking the patient to bear down gently helps relax the external sphincter and can make the urethral meatus wink/open, making it easier to locate.
questions.hint: The Valsalva maneuver helps visualize the opening.

questions.question: Which type of seizure may only affect a finger or hand?
questions.explanation: Simple partial seizures (focal seizures) affect a specific localized area of the motor cortex, causing twitching in just one part of the body without loss of consciousness.
questions.hint: It is focal (localized) and simple (no loss of consciousness).

questions.question: Microorganisms that have both bacterial and viral characteristics (intracellular but susceptible to antibiotics) include:
questions.explanation: Rickettsia and Chlamydia are obligate intracellular parasites (like viruses) but have cell walls and DNA/RNA (like bacteria) and respond to antibiotics.
questions.hint: They live inside cells like viruses but are killed by antibiotics.

questions.question: Impetigo contagiosa is caused by:
questions.explanation: Impetigo is a highly contagious bacterial skin infection caused by Staph aureus or Strep pyogenes.
questions.hint: Honey-colored crusts caused by bacteria.

questions.question: Buck’s traction is:

options.text: A form of skin traction used to relieve muscle spasms
A form of skeletal traction for compound fractures
Only used in correction of hip fractures

questions.explanation: Buck's traction is a longitudinal skin traction applied to the lower leg, commonly used pre-operatively for hip fractures to reduce muscle spasms and maintain alignment.
questions.hint: It pulls on the skin, not the bone, to stop spasms.
